title: Online Submodular Set Cover, Ranking, and Repeated Active Learning

author: Jeff A. Bilmes, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Washington

segmentation: So one application of our work is online ranking.
Let's suppose that were in the following situation where a user wants to learn about a particular topic and so enters a search query to a search engine.

The learner then comes back with a ranked list of links that the user then reads in order, and then the learner then gets penalized by the number of links that the user needs to read before the learner before the user learns fully about the topic.
So the key thing about this paper is that the loss of the learner is the number of items needed.
To achieve some coverage objective.
An another application is repeated active learning.
Here, for example, would be an example would be where a patient goes to see a doctor.

Anna Doctor then comes up with a ranked list of tests that the user that the patient needs to undergo, and then the learner who's the doctor in this case then suffers a penalty, which is the number of tests that need to be administered to the patient before the doctor is able to make an accurate diagnosis of what the problem is with the patient so.
Basically the problem is what we're calling.
The general problem is online submodular set cover.
So the way this works is that each round the learner then chooses a sequence of some underlying ground, set the finite ground set SAT.

Then what is revealed to the learner is either full information or some partial information about a monotone submodular objective function F of T. And then the learner then pays the cost, which is the number of items in that order until the submodular function exceeds some threshold.
So in this particular case, we assume that there's so much functions are normalized so that the threshold can be expressed as a value of the similar function exceeding one.
This constitutes a number of different instances.
For example, version space in active learning.

The example we saw before is when FT is proportional to the number of candidate diseases eliminated by the set of tests, and I guess we should point out that this is quite distinct from the other online submodular function optimization methods that have been proposed recently, including the online subtitrare maximization, an unline min some, some modular set cover of St and Golovin from a couple of years ago.
So the results, all the details of which you can see in the poster, or that there's a low regret algorithm for online so much or set cover.
And it builds up some recent offline results of Zorn Gamsu for online.
So much for offline similar ranking and we have extensions to handle the bandit setting and multiple objectives and partial information.
And the bandit setting.
And then we have some experimental results on both synthetic data and on a movie recommendation database where the goal is to come up with a list of movies for people to see.
